quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Revolut values way more raw intellect and this unquenched hunger to build things rather than experience.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A hiring and talent-development philosophy that prioritizes learning velocity and builder mindset over domain tenure.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It's not getting traction. Is it because the underlying idea is wrong? Or maybe your product just sucks?
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A diagnostic framing that forces teams to separate idea risk from execution/quality risk when early products stall.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We can cut down the product in terms of functionality to just most critical features, but we will never compromise on the quality and UX and the aesthetics.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A practical product strategy: reduce scope aggressively while holding the bar on craft to drive love and clarity in signals.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If something is 99% done, it's closer to 0% rather than 100%.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A memorable mental model emphasizing that unfinished work often delivers near-zero user value until fully shipped and polished.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Stripe
quotes.text: Stripe Billing lets you bill and manage customers however you want from simple recurring billing to usage-based billing to sales-negotiated contracts.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical monetization toolkit and flexibility in billing models that teams can apply when designing pricing and revenue operations.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Stripe
quotes.text: There's also Stripe's Optimized Checkout suite, which is a plug-and-play super optimized payment flow that natively supports over 100 global dynamic payment methods.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable product insight: improving checkout UX and supporting many payment methods can directly impact conversion and global expansion.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Stripe
quotes.text: Every single one of the Forbes top 50 AI companies that have a product in the market today use Stripe to monetize it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete market example signaling Stripe’s dominance in monetization infrastructure for leading AI companies.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Stripe
quotes.text: $1.4 trillion flows through Stripe annually, which is equivalent to over 1% of global GDP.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Memorable scale data point that quantifies Stripe’s reach and reliability as payments infrastructure.

quotes.topic_title: What Revolut is and why it won
quotes.text: I've been looking at which companies alumni product managers get promoted most when they leave the company, become chief product officers at the highest rate when they leave the company, become the first PM at a startup, also start their own companies.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete, multi-signal methodology for benchmarking which companies produce the strongest PM talent.

quotes.topic_title: What Revolut is and why it won
quotes.text: when I triangulate it across all these different data points, there's three companies that are kind of sat at the top, you guys, Revolut, Palantir, and Intercom.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific comparative data point naming the top companies by Lenny’s PM-outcomes triangulation.

quotes.topic_title: What Revolut is and why it won
quotes.text: Overall, there are 25 different currencies and every time you were traveling and paying in a different currency, banks were charging you exorbitant fees on top of terrible foreign exchange rates, and that's when Revolut launched as a multi-currency card and people loved it.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A crisp example of starting from a sharp, widespread pain point (FX fees + bad rates) and building an initial wedge product around it.

quotes.topic_title: What Revolut is and why it won
quotes.text: They loved that Revolut was saving them 50 or 100 euros, but even more so they loved the transparency and simplicity of the product and that's why when we started rolling out more and more products based on those principles, they were quickly getting trust of people.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A counterintuitive insight that trust and adoption can be driven more by transparency/simplicity than by pure monetary savings, guiding how to scale product lines.

quotes.topic_title: Product owners as “local CEOs”
quotes.text: Yeah, it's not a scrum term for us, it's just our take on emphasizing how ownership is important, really.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Reframes the “product owner” title as an intentional cultural mechanism to drive true ownership, not a process artifact.

quotes.topic_title: Product owners as “local CEOs”
quotes.text: So product owners are central to the company and its growth. They are end-to-end responsible for the product, for this part of the business, and for their customers to be happy.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Defines a clear accountability model: PMs own outcomes end-to-end, including customer happiness and business impact.

quotes.topic_title: Product owners as “local CEOs”
quotes.text: They run the teams, they define which roadmap we need to build to improve certain business metrics, and they also contribute to high-level company strategy, but then most importantly, they execute on it relentlessly and they are ultimate responsible for the product to be shipped and achieve results.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A concrete operating model for PMs: lead the team, tie roadmap to metrics, influence strategy, and own execution to results.

quotes.topic_title: Product owners as “local CEOs”
quotes.text: Yeah, but that's true. So the way we operate, we have these fully cross-functional teams, meaning they're staffed with all necessary functions, engineers data, analysts, designers, operational managers and so on.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Describes the structural prerequisite for “local CEO” PMs: autonomous, fully staffed cross-functional teams.

quotes.topic_title: Product owners as “local CEOs”
quotes.text: And we also operate in metrics. So everyone has a line manager and a functional manager. So product owner is always the line manager for everyone on the team, meaning product owner defines what they need to do, but then functional managers, they define how these things are need to be built and essentially with the right level of quality and so on.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Introduces a dual-management model that separates “what” (line manager/PO) from “how/quality” (functional manager) while staying metrics-driven.

quotes.topic_title: Three product owner archetypes and core skills
quotes.text: So the first type is UX product owners. Then there are technical product owners, and then there are data science product owners.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Introduces a clear three-archetype framework for product owners that teams can use to map roles and strengths.

quotes.topic_title: Three product owner archetypes and core skills
quotes.text: So what we see sometimes is people just shifting them because I would say that what defines the specialization is probably 5, 10, 15% while 85 to 90% is common to each one of them.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A counterintuitive claim that most PO effectiveness is transferable across specializations, enabling mobility and flexible staffing.

quotes.topic_title: Three product owner archetypes and core skills
quotes.text: And those things are, so first of all, being a great problem solver and have a great linear thinking, but also have a creative approach towards nonlinear problems.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Defines a practical core skill set: combine structured reasoning with creativity for messy, real-world product problems.

quotes.topic_title: Three product owner archetypes and core skills
quotes.text: And that means that you also need to be quite technical, even if you are an expert, you still need to often go as deep as sitting with engineers and reading code.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Sets a high bar for “going deep” that practitioners can operationalize by pairing with engineers and inspecting implementation details.

quotes.topic_title: Three product owner archetypes and core skills
quotes.text: And then I would also emphasize the importance of business acumen because we tend to measure and quantify product performance a lot.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Highlights that strong product ownership requires metric literacy and business thinking, not just UX/tech/data expertise.

quotes.topic_title: Going deep: regulatory launches and scalable processes
quotes.text: To launch a branch, you need to fully comply with all necessary regulation. You need to report necessary data on customers to various regulators and authorities. You need to register with local payment systems. And each of these things, they have a lot of projects nested within.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Concrete example of the real operational depth required for regulatory launches, highlighting the nested-project nature of compliance work.

quotes.topic_title: Going deep: regulatory launches and scalable processes
quotes.text: We have a very lean team of just a few people who need to scope everything and do it at the scale of 50 countries.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A specific scale constraint that forces process rigor and prioritization—useful for teams designing scalable operating models.

quotes.topic_title: Going deep: regulatory launches and scalable processes
quotes.text: Then we reverse engineered what was the best process to do it, and then we went back up on top level and we said, okay, but what's the ideal framework of doing it at scale?
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A repeatable methodology: do one or two launches deeply, reverse-engineer success, then generalize into a scalable framework.

quotes.topic_title: Going deep: regulatory launches and scalable processes
quotes.text: And then we formalized it into a process really like an algorithmic process with steps and quality gates and assay needs, what people do we need to hire and how soon do we need to start doing that before we want to launch a new country.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Actionable process design guidance: codify complex work into an “algorithm” with gates, resourcing, and lead-time planning.

quotes.topic_title: Going deep: regulatory launches and scalable processes
quotes.text: Then, so it's not only going deep, but also being flexible and doing this switch between zooming in very deep and then raising on the level of helicopter view and then understanding, okay, so this seems very, very complex in details, but then when you zoom out, how can we simplify it and build a robust process around it, which is scalable?
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A memorable mental model (“zoom in” vs. “helicopter view”) for turning complexity into scalable systems.

quotes.topic_title: Obsession with building “wow” products
quotes.text: I would probably add an obsession with building wow product.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A simple, memorable principle that elevates product quality beyond functional delivery—especially in categories that underinvest in delight.

quotes.topic_title: Obsession with building “wow” products
quotes.text: I think in FinTech overall, this is probably the most neglected part usually, but it's also a part that we at Revolut, we pay enormous attention to.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A contrarian observation that “wow” UX is a competitive advantage in fintech because most players ignore it.

quotes.topic_title: Obsession with building “wow” products
quotes.text: But we also pay a lot of attention to look and feel of the app and how smooth it is and how frictionless the process.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Actionable product guidance: treat polish, smoothness, and friction reduction as first-class requirements, not finishing touches.

quotes.topic_title: Obsession with building “wow” products
quotes.text: And I think people that work at Revolut, they built habit of paying attention to these small nuances, small details that make the product lovable.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A practical training model: build a team habit around noticing and improving the small details that drive user love.

quotes.topic_title: Obsession with building “wow” products
quotes.text: And I think this ability to keep this large context in your mind and consider second order effects and view subjects from multiple angles, I think that this is also a very important skill that people usually train at Revolut.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A mental model for strong PMs: hold broad context, anticipate second-order effects, and evaluate decisions from multiple angles.

quotes.topic_title: How wow quality is enforced: founder reviews
quotes.text: Two things that you need to understand about how Revolut operates is that we operate in small lean teams that are tasked to build products and as I mentioned, and having end-to-end responsibility for products.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Highlights Revolut’s operating model: small teams with true end-to-end ownership, a replicable structure for speed and accountability.

quotes.topic_title: How wow quality is enforced: founder reviews
quotes.text: And every week they have product reviews with every team giving an opportunity to every product owner present directly to CEO and CTO and show what increment has team achieved in the last week, but also get steering from founders, which is super valuable.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Describes a concrete cadence (weekly founder reviews) that enforces quality and alignment through direct feedback loops.

quotes.topic_title: How wow quality is enforced: founder reviews
quotes.text: Essentially founders of the company, they still review a hundred percent of screens that are being shipped and everything that you will see in the app pass this review.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A striking quality-control mechanism: founder review as a gate for all shipped UI, setting a consistent bar across teams.

quotes.topic_title: How wow quality is enforced: founder reviews
quotes.text: And there are a lot of eyeballs that were scrutinizing this and thinking of all possible edge cases and nuances that we need to consider to make sure that every single customer will be happy in this product, in this flow.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Emphasizes systematic edge-case scrutiny as a method to achieve “wow” quality in customer-facing flows.

quotes.topic_title: How wow quality is enforced: founder reviews
quotes.text: Oh, I'm afraid to say it's already more than 150 people, maybe 170.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Provides scale context: founder involvement and review processes persist even with ~150–170 product owners.

quotes.topic_title: Customer feedback loops at massive scale
quotes.text: Well maybe even it's way more important to have this hunger for building things and having the raw intellect.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Highlights a hiring heuristic that prioritizes intrinsic motivation and cognitive ability over years of PM experience.

quotes.topic_title: Customer feedback loops at massive scale
quotes.text: So it's like a positive self-select, so it means that someone already succeeded in another role. So it's a guaranteed culture match, it's a guaranteed domain knowledge, and then they simply grow.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Provides a practical rationale for internal transfers as a reliable pipeline for successful product owners.

quotes.topic_title: Customer feedback loops at massive scale
quotes.text: We've also built tools for product owners and designers to have an easy access to a panel of users via different tools so that they can just start an interviewing process or a survey or a test of different designs in a few clicks.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Describes an operational method for scaling customer feedback loops by making research execution near-frictionless.

quotes.topic_title: Customer feedback loops at massive scale
quotes.text: For me, it was very important to build this direct connection to customers because when you delegate such an important thing as customer research and collecting their feedback to someone, you will get a refined filtered version.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Argues for unmediated customer contact to avoid losing critical nuance in secondhand research summaries.

quotes.topic_title: Customer feedback loops at massive scale
quotes.text: It's very easy to lose all those important bytes of information in this process. So I'm a strong believer that it's very important to have direct communication channel to customers.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A memorable principle for preserving emotional and behavioral detail by keeping feedback loops direct.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring philosophy: raw intellect over experience
quotes.text: Revolut values way more raw intellect and this unquenched hunger to build things rather than experience.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A clear hiring principle that prioritizes innate problem-solving and drive over years-in-role credentials.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring philosophy: raw intellect over experience
quotes.text: what I see in product, the adoption curve is usually longer than in other functions because product owners by definition are the ones who are the experts in that domain and in all those intricacies of how product is built and how it's used.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A counterintuitive explanation for why even “experienced” PM hires can ramp slowly, shaping how you set expectations and hire.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring philosophy: raw intellect over experience
quotes.text: Unfortunately, professionals with a lot of years of experience from established companies, they don't have this strong urge to change status quo, which by the way will require toil, tears, and sweat.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A blunt warning about the motivational gap that can come with seniority and big-company backgrounds in high-change environments.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring philosophy: raw intellect over experience
quotes.text: one of the best profiles that I've seen is a tech co-founder.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A specific, high-signal candidate archetype to target when hiring for ownership, speed, and builder mindset.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring philosophy: raw intellect over experience
quotes.text: One of the great sources is actually looking into products and apps that we love ourselves. So if someone built a great product, then it's likely a high performer.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A practical sourcing method: reverse-recruit from products you admire to find proven builders.

quotes.topic_title: Sourcing tactics and recruiting in sprints
quotes.text: So the way we work, we have a weekly catch-ups with the recruitment team. So essentially they are also a team that runs in sprints.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Frames recruiting as an iterative sprint-based process with regular cadence and accountability.

quotes.topic_title: Sourcing tactics and recruiting in sprints
quotes.text: So every sprint we define what do we want to focus on, which areas, which companies.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A practical method for narrowing sourcing efforts by explicitly setting targets each sprint.

quotes.topic_title: Sourcing tactics and recruiting in sprints
quotes.text: One of the great sources is actually looking into products and apps that we love ourselves. So if someone built a great product, then it's likely a high performer.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A sourcing heuristic: start from admired products and work backward to the teams likely to contain strong builders.

quotes.topic_title: Sourcing tactics and recruiting in sprints
quotes.text: And so it varies from sprint to sprint.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Highlights that sourcing strategy should be dynamic and adapt to changing hiring needs rather than staying fixed.

quotes.topic_title: Sourcing tactics and recruiting in sprints
quotes.text: you look at there's successful companies, but then there's also what function in that company is the key to their success. And so you want to go like a company A for sales, company B for customer support, company C for design.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A targeted recruiting mental model: source by the specific function that made a company great, not just the company brand.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Stripe (repeat)
quotes.text: Every single one of the Forbes top 50 AI companies that has a product in the market today uses Stripe to monetize it.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Stripe ad read)
quotes.context: Strong social-proof data point suggesting Stripe is a default monetization stack for leading AI companies.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Stripe (repeat)
quotes.text: $1.4 trillion flows through Stripe annually, which is equivalent to over 1% of the entire global GDP.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Stripe ad read)
quotes.context: Scale benchmark that signals reliability and global reach for teams evaluating payment infrastructure risk.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Stripe (repeat)
quotes.text: Stripe Billing lets you bill and manage customers no matter your pricing model from simple recurring billing to usage-based billing to sales negotiated contracts.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Stripe ad read)
quotes.context: Actionable capability statement for practitioners designing pricing/packaging and needing flexible billing primitives.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Stripe (repeat)
quotes.text: Use Stripe to handle all of your payment related needs, including billing, revenue operations, checkout flows, or simply launching or inventing new business models.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Stripe ad read)
quotes.context: Memorable “payments as a platform” framing that encourages teams to treat monetization infrastructure as an enabler of experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership approach: deep dives to drive discipline
quotes.text: But how we did differently at Revolut is to go very deep into details. We take maybe 7 or 10 projects which are most impactful for customers right now. And we go super deep into them, really, really deep sitting with engineers like reading code level and understanding, okay, how it's built exactly and what's the underlying issue.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A concrete leadership operating model: pick a small set of highest-impact initiatives and deep-dive to the implementation level to drive outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership approach: deep dives to drive discipline
quotes.text: But the thing is that it actually, it's counterintuitive, but it works really well because first of all, teams, they talk to each other, there are formal and informal ways of communicating through meetups or just meeting in the office and they know which areas are being scrutinized right now and which team is being scrutinized.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Explains the mechanism for why selective deep scrutiny scales: social information flow spreads priorities and raises the bar beyond the reviewed teams.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership approach: deep dives to drive discipline
quotes.text: And it also gives information on what are the current priorities in the company.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Highlights deep dives as a signaling tool—what leadership inspects becomes the organization’s de facto priority list.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership approach: deep dives to drive discipline
quotes.text: But in addition, it's signaled to other teams that if they are not proactively executing things on the expected level, paying attention to all the details and being meticulous in all those details, especially in quality, they will be the ones that will be reviewed to a such deep level, next phase, next cycle. So as a result, it also builds a great discipline.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A practical accountability lever: deep reviews create an incentive for autonomous teams to maintain high quality without constant oversight.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership approach: deep dives to drive discipline
quotes.text: Maybe closer to a hundred, actually.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A specific data point that quantifies the scale of parallel execution this model is designed to handle.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling breadth: platform leverage across 50 countries
quotes.text: But by giving people autonomy, they actually boost company growth.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Highlights autonomy as a deliberate scaling lever rather than a cultural nice-to-have.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling breadth: platform leverage across 50 countries
quotes.text: Another thing here is what I mentioned previously is us investing heavily into platform so that every solution is scalable from the get go so that we don't have any custom solutions.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A clear platform-first methodology for scaling across markets by avoiding one-off builds.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling breadth: platform leverage across 50 countries
quotes.text: And for example, take our credit team, they ship new products like loans or credit cards in the country literally every month.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Concrete operating cadence that demonstrates how platform leverage translates into shipping velocity.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling breadth: platform leverage across 50 countries
quotes.text: And it is just maybe 300 people. And I think that a credit division in an incumbent bank is maybe 2 or 3000 people building just credit products for a single country.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Striking benchmark that challenges assumptions about headcount needed to deliver regulated financial products.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling breadth: platform leverage across 50 countries
quotes.text: And our team is building it for 50 countries.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A vivid scale example showing how a lean org can operate globally when built on reusable platforms.

quotes.topic_title: Product breadth and market opportunity
quotes.text: Yeah, 50 different jurisdictions each with its own regulation, with its own requirements.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Highlights the operational/regulatory complexity as a core scaling challenge (and moat) when expanding product breadth globally.

quotes.topic_title: Product breadth and market opportunity
quotes.text: Oh, boy. It's a good example of Paul Graham has this concept of schlep blindness or schlepping where people want to avoid hard problems, but that's where the big opportunities are, solving really gnarly, painful problems. And that's basically what you guys did.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: leaning into “schlep” problems can be a durable source of advantage and market opportunity.

quotes.topic_title: Product breadth and market opportunity
quotes.text: When I joined, we had maybe just slightly north to 20 million customers. Now we are 50 million customers. Soon we'll be at 100 million customers.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Concrete growth trajectory data that signals scale potential and the pace at which product ecosystems can expand.

quotes.topic_title: Product breadth and market opportunity
quotes.text: So we can easily do another, I don't know, 2, 3X, 4X in customer base growth, but we can also do another 10X growth in how actively these people are using the product.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Actionable growth lens: don’t just chase new users—drive step-change increases in engagement/primary-bank usage via ecosystem depth.

quotes.topic_title: Product breadth and market opportunity
quotes.text: I think we have maybe 3 or 400 open positions currently.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A specific hiring datapoint that indicates the scale of execution required to pursue broad product and market expansion.

quotes.topic_title: Launching new products: new bets framework
quotes.text: So we built a new bets framework and essentially everyone can come up with a new idea. It could be a product owner, but it could be anyone, and they need to show some key important things which you usually can expect from a startup like market is there, business case is there.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A lightweight, startup-style gating framework that broadens idea sourcing beyond PMs while still requiring market and business-case rigor.

quotes.topic_title: Launching new products: new bets framework
quotes.text: And there is very little bureaucracy, again, thanks to having founder hands-on, we can easily get a green light on anything, start launching it quickly.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Highlights how minimizing approval layers can materially speed up experimentation and time-to-launch.

quotes.topic_title: Launching new products: new bets framework
quotes.text: What we do is assemble same lean team with just a few people to build first version and then iterate and iterate.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A repeatable operating model: small teams ship an initial version fast and improve through tight iteration loops.

quotes.topic_title: Launching new products: new bets framework
quotes.text: And the main thing here is to build first version very quickly to get feedback, but then not scale it before you polish the product. But then after we make sure that all metrics are fine, retention is great, we start scaling it.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Counterbalances “ship fast” with a clear rule: don’t scale until quality and retention/metrics prove readiness.

quotes.topic_title: Launching new products: new bets framework
quotes.text: So for example, one of the products that you mentioned, joint accounts essentially an account that you could have with a significant other one was one of the recently launched feature and it grew significantly and now it has over a million active users.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Concrete traction example showing how a validated product can scale quickly once distributed through Revolut’s base.

quotes.topic_title: No scrappy MVPs: narrow scope, high polish
quotes.text: The thing is that when you launch a scrappy version and it's not getting traction, how do you know? Is it because the underlying idea is wrong or maybe your product just sucks and you need to improve it?
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Highlights the confounding-variable problem with scrappy MVPs: low traction may reflect poor execution rather than a bad idea.

quotes.topic_title: No scrappy MVPs: narrow scope, high polish
quotes.text: So by forcing everyone to build a product that people will love by building a wow product, we kind of cut out this part of uncertainty.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A methodology for early validation: increase UX quality to reduce ambiguity in interpreting market feedback.

quotes.topic_title: No scrappy MVPs: narrow scope, high polish
quotes.text: So bottom line, we can cut down the product in terms of functionality to just most critical features, but we will never compromise on the quality and UX and the aesthetics.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A clear product principle: narrow scope is acceptable, but polish is non-negotiable for v1.

quotes.topic_title: No scrappy MVPs: narrow scope, high polish
quotes.text: An interesting advantage you guys have that I'm realizing as you talk is most of the stuff you launch is stuff that is clearly something people will want because it's stuff that they get other places, but they get the advantages of it being integrated into all the other features and products you have.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Frames a strategy for de-risking new launches: build proven-demand features and win via integration into an existing product ecosystem.

quotes.topic_title: Table stakes vs delighters in banking UX
quotes.text: So I think there are those kind of table stakes that we're building that anyone would expect from a bank.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Introduces a clear mental model for separating must-have baseline features from differentiators in product strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Table stakes vs delighters in banking UX
quotes.text: But then we make sure that our rates are very competitive, if not the best. Then we make sure that there is no bad UX.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: even “table stakes” features can be won through best-in-class economics and eliminating UX friction.

quotes.topic_title: Table stakes vs delighters in banking UX
quotes.text: We will allow you if you want to move money out, you will be able to do it. You won't lose any interest. And interest is being paid daily and this is a fully flexible product.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Concrete example of turning a basic savings account into a superior experience via instant liquidity and daily interest.

quotes.topic_title: Table stakes vs delighters in banking UX
quotes.text: So there is an underlying basic fundamental layer that where you need to be just on par with competition, but then there are a lot of things on top that just make people love your product way more.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Memorable articulation of the “baseline + delighters” layering approach to product design and prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Table stakes vs delighters in banking UX
quotes.text: So yeah, thinking of crypto, you can just receive crypto on your wallet and then you can just instantly convert it to cash on your account or just spend it with your card. How amazing can it be? Just buy a coffee with Ethereum.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Specific synergy example showing how integration across products can create standout “wow” moments users remember.

quotes.topic_title: Summary of Revolut PM “forge” and execution mindset
quotes.text: So in what you do internally, kind of the four bullet points I've got here is give people a lot of ownership. They're essentially GMs of the product, the feature.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A clear operating model for developing PMs: treat them like mini-GMs with end-to-end ownership.

quotes.topic_title: Summary of Revolut PM “forge” and execution mindset
quotes.text: First is let's say being technical, understanding how underlying systems work, but second is also building empathy towards customers. Understand the possible contexts and making sure that your product will satisfy each one of them.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A two-stream depth model: pair technical “how it works” understanding with customer-context empathy to build better products.

quotes.topic_title: Summary of Revolut PM “forge” and execution mindset
quotes.text: I would say it's actually being able to unblock your team and that sometimes require product owners to steam roll changes because it also means that you could easily get stuck with a lot of people just looking into each other and thinking, "Okay, can they approve it? Can they not approve it?"
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A contrarian take on stakeholder management: PMs sometimes must force momentum to avoid approval paralysis.

quotes.topic_title: Summary of Revolut PM “forge” and execution mindset
quotes.text: Most importantly, it's again, getting things done, getting your hands dirty, and great product owners are very hands-on.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: Practical career advice: high-performing PMs execute directly rather than operating purely through delegation.

quotes.topic_title: Summary of Revolut PM “forge” and execution mindset
quotes.text: they understand that there needs to be relentless focus on execution, and if something is 99% done, it's closer to 0% rather than 100%.
quotes.speaker: Dmitry Zlokazov
quotes.context: A memorable execution mantra that reframes “almost done” as still far from shipped value.
